caseTitle: KLIMATECHNIK ENGINEERING LTD v. SKANSKA JENSEN INTERNATIONAL
summary: This Supreme Court of Ghana case, KLIMATECHNIK ENGINEERING LTD v. SKANSKA JENSEN INTERNATIONAL (CIVIL APPEAL NO. 9/2000, 23rd July 2003), arose from a dispute over unpaid HVAC subcontract work at the Golden Tulip Hotel. The plaintiff, a Cypriot engineering firm, performed over 90% of the work based on initialled draft terms and meeting minutes (Exhibit G), but the formal subcontract (Exhibit H) was never executed. The defendant terminated the engagement for failure to provide a performance bond, a clause in the unexecuted draft. The High Court and Court of Appeal found the termination unlawful, as the binding agreement was limited to Exhibit G, which did not require a bond. The courts awarded the plaintiff USD 224,533.29 on a quantum meruit basis for services rendered. The Supreme Court upheld these decisions, rejecting the defendant's counterclaim as unsubstantiated and affirming the validity of a foreign currency award in a restitution claim. The appeal was dismissed, reinforcing that substantial performance entitles a party to reasonable compensation even without a final signed contract.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; judgment in favor of the plaintiff upheld.
rationaleHighlights: The only binding contract was the minutes of meeting (Exhibit G), not the draft subcontract (Exhibit H).
Performance bond was not a condition precedent under Exhibit G; thus, termination on that ground was unlawful.
Claimant entitled to quantum meruit for services rendered despite lack of formal contract.
Counterclaim dismissed as a 'sham' due to lack of credible evidence.
Award in USD upheld as appropriate given the international nature of the contract.
Appellate courts correctly applied principles of contract and restitution law.
Failure to execute formal contract did not negate obligation to pay for work done.
Court had jurisdiction despite alleged arbitration clause.
